Comment: micaceous, homogeneous v.f. sandy marl; partly mottled with mud color (5GY 4/1)
v.f. sandy marl; micaceous, homogeneous, color-mottled, coarsens-up & sandier-up from the bottom.
micaceous, homogeneous marl (silty); mottled,  with a few v.f. sand.
micaceous, homogeneous marl (silty); mottled,  with a few v.f. sand.
marly, shelly f. sand; homogeneous with abundant shell fragments.
Mud with a few percent v f sand
poorly sorted v f to medium mostly f shelly sand.

Sandy mud.  Mud is clay-rich.  Sand is moderately to poorly sorted, contains up to medium (L)-size grains (mostly bioclasts). The remainder of the sand is vf sand.  Very common shell fragments (Stiracolpus, Tawera) up to 1.5 cm in size (concentrated @7-8 cm).

12-15 cm Sandy marlstone concretion containing Crassostrea fragments (also at 28-30 cm).  Sharp contact at 38 cm.  Contains several well-rounded quartz pebbles ( up to 2.5 cm long) and bored carbonate fragment (1.5 cm long), which appears to be a fragment of the larger versions of this lithotype observed in sections higher in the hole.  Also common shell fragments are observed in this interval.
Calcareous sandy mud.  Sand is vf-f (mostly vf) and associated with burrows, which extended down to 92 cm from the contact at 38 cm.  Common shell fragments.
Calcareous mud with minor amount of sand (vf) and common shell fragments.

Homogenous calcareous mud with minor amounts of vf, well-sorted sand, slightly micaceous.  Vf sand is more concentrated in burrows (up to 5 mm is size), which are more common in the upper 30 cm of the section.

More concentrated shell fragments in discrete layers.  These layers also contain poorly sorted sand mixed with shell fragments, with maximum size of fragment noted below in parentheses.
37-42 cm (3 mm max size)
86-88 cm( 2 mm max size)

Common shell fragments and whole Stiracolpus (gastropods)  throughout the remainder of section.

Homogenous calcareous mud with trace/minor amounts of vf, well-sorted sand, slightly micaceous.  Vf sand is more concentrated in the upper 60 cm of the section.  A clay-rich interval is noted between 95-97.

More concentrated shell fragments in discrete layers.  These layers also contain poorly sorted sand mixed with shell fragments, with maximum size of fragment noted below in parentheses.
61-64 cm (3 mm max size), also contains a scaphopod (1 cm long)
80-81 cm( 3 mm max size)


Common to scattered shells from 0-80 cm; rare shell fragments 80-140 cm.

Homogenous calcareous mud with minor amount of vf, well-sorted sand, slightly micaceous.  Vf sand becomes more concentrated down section.  

Very common shell fragments (mostly Stiracolpus) below 30 cm.  Fragments up to 5 mm in size but in general are mostly just a few mm or less.
Homogenous calcareous sandy mud.  Sand is  vf, well-sorted sand, slightly micaceous.
Homogenous calcareous sandy mud.  Sand is  vf, well-sorted sand, slightly micaceous.
Sandy mud.  Poorly sorted vf-med shelly sandy mud.  Shells dominated by broken bivalves and Stiracolpus.  Probably fall-in.  Gradational base.  Venerid bivalves at 5-8 and 20-38 cm.

Muddy sand with gradational base.  Moderately sorted vf-medium (mostly fine) v shelly muddy sand.  Shells dominated by broken bivalves.  Sandier intervals with few shells.  Not certain if this is in place (but has the appearance of concrete mix.  Shell dissolution?).  At 89 to 112 cm, 10Y 5/1 < 2 cm diam vf to f sandy mud ?blebs? , could be burrows.
Very calcareous mud with a few % micaceous vf to f sand.  Shells scattered throughout, including Stiracolpus, but mostly are finely broken fragments.
Shelly sandy marl. Contains vf to f (mostly f) sand.  Mesopeplum at 52 cm.  Gradational upward into more muddy marl.  Calcareous nodules common, e.g., 26-27 cm, 38-42 cm, 51-53 cm, 77-80 cm.
Moderately sorted vf-med (mostly fine) sandy marl with incipient calcareous concretions.  Shells broken.
Moderately sorted vf-medium (mostly f) shelly marl with Stiracoplus gastropods.
well sorted, vf-f (mostly f) micaceous gray sand.  Gradational base.
vf sandy clayey mud, sharp basal contact.  122-125.  Poorly sorted, vf-coarse shelly sand
vf to med sandy marl with abundant broken shells including Maorricolpus.
mod sorted vf-med (mostly fine) shelly sandy marl with venerids and Stiracolpus.  Burrowed basal contact; burrows extend down to 28 cm.

Mud with a few % vf sand.  Rare scattered shells (e.g., 56 cm).  Slightly calcareous and micaceous.  Also contains numerous gray (N5) clay-rich mud layers, increasing in abundance from 100 cm (esp. 100-107 cm in sec 3).  Beds up to 2 cm thick

Mud with a few % vf sand.  Rare scattered shells (e.g., 56 cm).  Slightly calcareous and micaceous.  Also contains numerous gray (N5) clay-rich mud layers, increasing in abundance from 100 cm (esp. 100-107 cm in sec 3).  Beds up to 2 cm thick
v.f. sandy mud with bioclast medium to 3 mm size
v.f. sandy marl, biogenic clast (medium sand to 10 mm size)
muddy shelly bioclastic sand and v.f.-f.sand; fining-u, with bivalve shell fragments <5mm
poorly-sorted shelly muddy  v.f.-m.sand; with shell fragments <5mm
poorly-sorted shelly v.f.-m.sandy mud; with shell fragments <5mm
poorly-sorted shelly muddy  v.f.-m.sand; with shell fragments <5mm
poorly-sorted shelly muddy  v.f.-m.sand; with shell fragments <5mm
poorly-sorted shelly muddy  v.f.-m.sand; with shell fragments <5mm

clay-rich mud with intercalated normally graded sand laminations.  Each lamination has a sharp base and is composed of vf-f (mostly f) well sorted dark gray sand, slightly micaceous, and of possible Torlesse provenance.

Slightly sandy mud with a trace to minor % vf-f (mostly vf), well sorted slightly micaceous sand. Sand is both disseminated in the mud and more concentrated into burrows that are mostly a few mm in diameter but up to 2 cm (46-47 cm in section 1).   It contains rare scattered, broken shell fragments (mostly bivalve), but includes larger fragments of barnacles and Chlamys del. (?).

Slightly sandy mud with a trace to minor % vf-f (mostly vf), well sorted slightly micaceous sand. Sand is both disseminated in the mud and more concentrated into burrows that are mostly a few mm in diameter but up to 2 cm (46-47 cm in section 1).   It contains rare scattered, broken shell fragments (mostly bivalve), but includes larger fragments of barnacles and Chlamys del. (?).
Mud with a few percent v f sand
Clay with a few percent v f sand
Well sorted v f to f sand
Poorly sorted vf to crs sandy mud
well sorted v f to f (mostly f) sand. - Torlesse sand

Homogeneous to faintly laminated mud.  Contains trace to minor amount of vf-f sand.  Mud appears to be clay-rich, with notable clayey intervals at 25-27, 39-42, 50-53, 90-91 cm. Faint color banding throughout at ~ 3cm intervals-probable biscuiting. Erosional boundary at 90 cm between vf well-sorted, micaceous sand overlying clay.  Small shell fragments scattered throughout section, with more concentrated intervals at 23-24, 61, 74, and 84 cm, that also contains slightly more vf sand.

Homogeneous to faintly laminated mud.  Contains trace to minor amount of vf-f sand.  Mud appears to be clay-rich, with notable clayey intervals at 14-15, 51-52, 70-71, 75-76, 80-81 cm.
Dispersed/scattered small shell fragments throughout, but concentrated into layer at 32, 92, 121-122 cm that also contains slightly more vf sand. . Faint color banding throughout at ~ 3cm intervals-probable biscuiting.

Homogeneous mud.  Contains trace to minor amount of vf-f sand.  Slightly more shell fragments than earlier sections. Faint color banding is not as apparent as in previous sections. Small shell fragments scattered throughout section, with more concentrated intervals at 47-49, 56-57, 69-70, 75-79, 83-86,100-102, 117, 129-133 cm.  Most fragments are small (a few mm) and very broken, but there are some larger (~1 cm) fragments (e.g., 34-35, 78-79 cm) that are scallop and bivalve fragments.


56-57 silt-rich lamination, with common small (~1 mm) sized shell fragments.

Homogeneous mud, slightly calcareous with minor amounts of vf-f (mostly vf) sand.  Common small shell fragments, sometimes concentrated into layers.  Greater concentration of vf-f sand associated with these layers.  More discernible layers at 0-4, 10-14, 29-31, 35-40, also contains a few larger shell fragments up to 1 cm in size.  Shelly intervals become more concentrated below 40 cm.

Shelly sandy marl.  Sand ranges from vf-m, mostly vf, with the coarser component mostly/completely bioclasts.  Poorly sorted.  Larger (>1 mm) shell fragments are common and are also poorly sorted, ranging from a few mm up to 2 cm.

Shelly sandy marl, with incipient calcareous nodule formation throughout.  Sand ranges from vf-m, mostly vf, with the coarser component mostly/completely bioclasts.  Poorly sorted.  Color change at 21 cm appears to be diagenetic, as there is no distinct textural change across the boundary.  No shell fragments are apparent below 21 cm.

Shelly sandy marl.  The sand is poorly sorted and ranges from vf-granular, mostly vf, with the coarser component mostly/completely bioclasts.  Larger (>1 mm) shell fragments are common and are also poorly sorted, ranging from a few mm up to 6 mm in the core catcher. There is incipient calcareous nodule formation throughout the core catcher with two large sandy shelly marlstone concretions present.  Color change at 17 cm in CC appears to be diagenetic, as there is no distinct textural change across the boundary.

Shelly sandy marl.  The sand is poorly sorted and ranges from vf-granular, mostly vf, with the coarser component mostly/completely bioclasts.  Larger (>1 mm) shell fragments are common and are also poorly sorted, ranging from a few mm up to 6 mm in the core catcher. There is incipient calcareous nodule formation throughout the core catcher with two large sandy shelly marlstone concretions present.  Color change at 17 cm in CC appears to be diagenetic, as there is no distinct textural change across the boundary.
Mud with a few percent v f sand. sometimes with clayey mud forming intervals up to 20 cm thick.
